       7             : /*
       8             :  * Implements (almost always) lock-free atomic operations. The operations here
       9             :  * are a subset of that which can be found in C++11's <atomic> header, with a
      10             :  * different API to enforce consistent memory ordering constraints.
      11             :  *
      12             :  * Anyone caught using |volatile| for inter-thread memory safety needs to be
      13             :  * sent a copy of this header and the C++11 standard.
      14             :  */
      15             : 
      16             : #ifndef mozilla_Atomics_h
      17             : #define mozilla_Atomics_h
      18             : 
      19             : #include "mozilla/Assertions.h"
      20             : #include "mozilla/Attributes.h"
      21             : #include "mozilla/Compiler.h"
      22             : #include "mozilla/TypeTraits.h"
      23             : 
      24             : #include <stdint.h>
      25             : 
      26             : /*
      27             :  * Our minimum deployment target on clang/OS X is OS X 10.6, whose SDK
      28             :  * does not have <atomic>.  So be sure to check for <atomic> support
      29             :  * along with C++0x support.
      30             :  */
      31             : #if defined(_MSC_VER)
      32             : #  define MOZ_HAVE_CXX11_ATOMICS
      33             : #elif defined(__clang__) || defined(__GNUC__)
      34             :    /*
      35             :     * Clang doesn't like <atomic> from libstdc++ before 4.7 due to the
      36             :     * loose typing of the atomic builtins. GCC 4.5 and 4.6 lacks inline
      37             :     * definitions for unspecialized std::atomic and causes linking errors.
      38             :     * Therefore, we require at least 4.7.0 for using libstdc++.
      39             :     *
      40             :     * libc++ <atomic> is only functional with clang.
      41             :     */
      42             : #  if MOZ_USING_LIBSTDCXX && MOZ_LIBSTDCXX_VERSION_AT_LEAST(4, 7, 0)
      43             : #    define MOZ_HAVE_CXX11_ATOMICS
      44             : #  elif MOZ_USING_LIBCXX && defined(__clang__)
      45             : #    define MOZ_HAVE_CXX11_ATOMICS
      46             : #  endif
      47             : #endif
      48             : 
      49             : namespace mozilla {
      50             : 
      51             : /**
      52             :  * An enum of memory ordering possibilities for atomics.
      53             :  *
      54             :  * Memory ordering is the observable state of distinct values in memory.
      55             :  * (It's a separate concept from atomicity, which concerns whether an
      56             :  * operation can ever be observed in an intermediate state.  Don't
      57             :  * conflate the two!)  Given a sequence of operations in source code on
      58             :  * memory, it is *not* always the case that, at all times and on all
      59             :  * cores, those operations will appear to have occurred in that exact
      60             :  * sequence.  First, the compiler might reorder that sequence, if it
      61             :  * thinks another ordering will be more efficient.  Second, the CPU may
      62             :  * not expose so consistent a view of memory.  CPUs will often perform
      63             :  * their own instruction reordering, above and beyond that performed by
      64             :  * the compiler.  And each core has its own memory caches, and accesses
      65             :  * (reads and writes both) to "memory" may only resolve to out-of-date
      66             :  * cache entries -- not to the "most recently" performed operation in
      67             :  * some global sense.  Any access to a value that may be used by
      68             :  * multiple threads, potentially across multiple cores, must therefore
      69             :  * have a memory ordering imposed on it, for all code on all
      70             :  * threads/cores to have a sufficiently coherent worldview.
      71             :  *
      72             :  * http://gcc.gnu.org/wiki/Atomic/GCCMM/AtomicSync and
      73             :  * http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/atomic/memory_order go into more
      74             :  * detail on all this, including examples of how each mode works.
      75             :  *
      76             :  * Note that for simplicity and practicality, not all of the modes in
      77             :  * C++11 are supported.  The missing C++11 modes are either subsumed by
      78             :  * the modes we provide below, or not relevant for the CPUs we support
      79             :  * in Gecko.  These three modes are confusing enough as it is!
      80             :  */
      81             : enum MemoryOrdering {
      82             :   /*
      83             :    * Relaxed ordering is the simplest memory ordering: none at all.
      84             :    * When the result of a write is observed, nothing may be inferred
      85             :    * about other memory.  Writes ostensibly performed "before" on the
      86             :    * writing thread may not yet be visible.  Writes performed "after" on
      87             :    * the writing thread may already be visible, if the compiler or CPU
      88             :    * reordered them.  (The latter can happen if reads and/or writes get
      89             :    * held up in per-processor caches.)  Relaxed ordering means
      90             :    * operations can always use cached values (as long as the actual
      91             :    * updates to atomic values actually occur, correctly, eventually), so
      92             :    * it's usually the fastest sort of atomic access.  For this reason,
      93             :    * *it's also the most dangerous kind of access*.
      94             :    *
      95             :    * Relaxed ordering is good for things like process-wide statistics
      96             :    * counters that don't need to be consistent with anything else, so
      97             :    * long as updates themselves are atomic.  (And so long as any
      98             :    * observations of that value can tolerate being out-of-date -- if you
      99             :    * need some sort of up-to-date value, you need some sort of other
     100             :    * synchronizing operation.)  It's *not* good for locks, mutexes,
     101             :    * reference counts, etc. that mediate access to other memory, or must
     102             :    * be observably consistent with other memory.
     103             :    *
     104             :    * x86 architectures don't take advantage of the optimization
     105             :    * opportunities that relaxed ordering permits.  Thus it's possible
     106             :    * that using relaxed ordering will "work" on x86 but fail elsewhere
     107             :    * (ARM, say, which *does* implement non-sequentially-consistent
     108             :    * relaxed ordering semantics).  Be extra-careful using relaxed
     109             :    * ordering if you can't easily test non-x86 architectures!
     110             :    */
     111             :   Relaxed,
     112             : 
     113             :   /*
     114             :    * When an atomic value is updated with ReleaseAcquire ordering, and
     115             :    * that new value is observed with ReleaseAcquire ordering, prior
     116             :    * writes (atomic or not) are also observable.  What ReleaseAcquire
     117             :    * *doesn't* give you is any observable ordering guarantees for
     118             :    * ReleaseAcquire-ordered operations on different objects.  For
     119             :    * example, if there are two cores that each perform ReleaseAcquire
     120             :    * operations on separate objects, each core may or may not observe
     121             :    * the operations made by the other core.  The only way the cores can
     122             :    * be synchronized with ReleaseAcquire is if they both
     123             :    * ReleaseAcquire-access the same object.  This implies that you can't
     124             :    * necessarily describe some global total ordering of ReleaseAcquire
     125             :    * operations.
     126             :    *
     127             :    * ReleaseAcquire ordering is good for (as the name implies) atomic
     128             :    * operations on values controlling ownership of things: reference
     129             :    * counts, mutexes, and the like.  However, if you are thinking about
     130             :    * using these to implement your own locks or mutexes, you should take
     131             :    * a good, hard look at actual lock or mutex primitives first.
     132             :    */
     133             :   ReleaseAcquire,
     134             : 
     135             :   /*
     136             :    * When an atomic value is updated with SequentiallyConsistent
     137             :    * ordering, all writes observable when the update is observed, just
     138             :    * as with ReleaseAcquire ordering.  But, furthermore, a global total
     139             :    * ordering of SequentiallyConsistent operations *can* be described.
     140             :    * For example, if two cores perform SequentiallyConsistent operations
     141             :    * on separate objects, one core will observably perform its update
     142             :    * (and all previous operations will have completed), then the other
     143             :    * core will observably perform its update (and all previous
     144             :    * operations will have completed).  (Although those previous
     145             :    * operations aren't themselves ordered -- they could be intermixed,
     146             :    * or ordered if they occur on atomic values with ordering
     147             :    * requirements.)  SequentiallyConsistent is the *simplest and safest*
     148             :    * ordering of atomic operations -- it's always as if one operation
     149             :    * happens, then another, then another, in some order -- and every
     150             :    * core observes updates to happen in that single order.  Because it
     151             :    * has the most synchronization requirements, operations ordered this
     152             :    * way also tend to be slowest.
     153             :    *
     154             :    * SequentiallyConsistent ordering can be desirable when multiple
     155             :    * threads observe objects, and they all have to agree on the
     156             :    * observable order of changes to them.  People expect
     157             :    * SequentiallyConsistent ordering, even if they shouldn't, when
     158             :    * writing code, atomic or otherwise.  SequentiallyConsistent is also
     159             :    * the ordering of choice when designing lockless data structures.  If
     160             :    * you don't know what order to use, use this one.
     161             :    */
     162             :   SequentiallyConsistent,
     163             : };
     164             : 
     165             : } // namespace mozilla
     166             : 
     167             : // Build up the underlying intrinsics.
     168             : #ifdef MOZ_HAVE_CXX11_ATOMICS
     169             : 
     170             : #  include <atomic>
     171             :

     176             :  * We provide CompareExchangeFailureOrder to work around a bug in some
     177             :  * versions of GCC's <atomic> header.  See bug 898491.
     178             :  */
     179             : template<MemoryOrdering Order> struct AtomicOrderConstraints;
     180             :

     188             :     std::memory_order_relaxed;

     190             : 
     191             : template<>
     192             : struct AtomicOrderConstraints<ReleaseAcquire>
     193             : {
     194             :   static const std::memory_order AtomicRMWOrder = std::memory_order_acq_rel;
     195             :   static const std::memory_order LoadOrder = std::memory_order_acquire;
     196             :   static const std::memory_order StoreOrder = std::memory_order_release;
     197             :   static const std::memory_order CompareExchangeFailureOrder =
     198             :     std::memory_order_acquire;
     199             : };
     200             : 
     201             : template<>
     202             : struct AtomicOrderConstraints<SequentiallyConsistent>
     203             : {
     204             :   static const std::memory_order AtomicRMWOrder = std::memory_order_seq_cst;
     205             :   static const std::memory_order LoadOrder = std::memory_order_seq_cst;
     206             :   static const std::memory_order StoreOrder = std::memory_order_seq_cst;
     207             :   static const std::memory_order CompareExchangeFailureOrder =
     208             :     std::memory_order_seq_cst;

     332             : #elif defined(__GNUC__)
     333             : 
     334             : namespace mozilla {
     335             : namespace detail {
     336             : 
     337             : /*
     338             :  * The __sync_* family of intrinsics is documented here:
     339             :  *
     340             :  * http://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc-4.6.4/gcc/Atomic-Builtins.html
     341             :  *
     342             :  * While these intrinsics are deprecated in favor of the newer __atomic_*
     343             :  * family of intrincs:
     344             :  *
     345             :  * http://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc-4.7.3/gcc/_005f_005fatomic-Builtins.html
     346             :  *
     347             :  * any GCC version that supports the __atomic_* intrinsics will also support
     348             :  * the <atomic> header and so will be handled above.  We provide a version of
     349             :  * atomics using the __sync_* intrinsics to support older versions of GCC.
     350             :  *
     351             :  * All __sync_* intrinsics that we use below act as full memory barriers, for
     352             :  * both compiler and hardware reordering, except for __sync_lock_test_and_set,
     353             :  * which is a only an acquire barrier.  When we call __sync_lock_test_and_set,
     354             :  * we add a barrier above it as appropriate.
     355             :  */
     356             : 
     357             : template<MemoryOrdering Order> struct Barrier;
     358             : 
     359             : /*
     360             :  * Some processors (in particular, x86) don't require quite so many calls to
     361             :  * __sync_sychronize as our specializations of Barrier produce.  If
     362             :  * performance turns out to be an issue, defining these specializations
     363             :  * on a per-processor basis would be a good first tuning step.
     364             :  */
     365             : 
     366             : template<>
     367             : struct Barrier<Relaxed>
     368             : {
     369             :   static void beforeLoad() {}
     370             :   static void afterLoad() {}
     371             :   static void beforeStore() {}
     372             :   static void afterStore() {}
     373             : };
     374             : 
     375             : template<>
     376             : struct Barrier<ReleaseAcquire>
     377             : {
     378             :   static void beforeLoad() {}
     379             :   static void afterLoad() { __sync_synchronize(); }
     380             :   static void beforeStore() { __sync_synchronize(); }
     381             :   static void afterStore() {}
     382             : };
     383             : 
     384             : template<>
     385             : struct Barrier<SequentiallyConsistent>
     386             : {
     387             :   static void beforeLoad() { __sync_synchronize(); }
     388             :   static void afterLoad() { __sync_synchronize(); }
     389             :   static void beforeStore() { __sync_synchronize(); }
     390             :   static void afterStore() { __sync_synchronize(); }
     391             : };
     392             : 
     393             : template<typename T, bool TIsEnum = IsEnum<T>::value>
     394             : struct AtomicStorageType
     395             : {
     396             :   // For non-enums, just use the type directly.
     397             :   typedef T Type;
     398             : };
     399             : 
     400             : template<typename T>
     401             : struct AtomicStorageType<T, true>
     402             :   : Conditional<sizeof(T) == 4, uint32_t, uint64_t>
     403             : {
     404             :   static_assert(sizeof(T) == 4 || sizeof(T) == 8,
     405             :                 "wrong type computed in conditional above");
     406             : };
     407             : 
     408             : template<typename T, MemoryOrdering Order>
     409             : struct IntrinsicMemoryOps
     410             : {
     411             :   typedef typename AtomicStorageType<T>::Type ValueType;
     412             : 
     413             :   static T load(const ValueType& aPtr)
     414             :   {
     415             :     Barrier<Order>::beforeLoad();
     416             :     T val = T(aPtr);
     417             :     Barrier<Order>::afterLoad();
     418             :     return val;
     419             :   }
     420             : 
     421             :   static void store(ValueType& aPtr, T aVal)
     422             :   {
     423             :     Barrier<Order>::beforeStore();
     424             :     aPtr = ValueType(aVal);
     425             :     Barrier<Order>::afterStore();
     426             :   }
     427             : 
     428             :   static T exchange(ValueType& aPtr, T aVal)
     429             :   {
     430             :     // __sync_lock_test_and_set is only an acquire barrier; loads and stores
     431             :     // can't be moved up from after to before it, but they can be moved down
     432             :     // from before to after it.  We may want a stricter ordering, so we need
     433             :     // an explicit barrier.
     434             :     Barrier<Order>::beforeStore();
     435             :     return T(__sync_lock_test_and_set(&aPtr, ValueType(aVal)));
     436             :   }
     437             : 
     438             :   static bool compareExchange(ValueType& aPtr, T aOldVal, T aNewVal)
     439             :   {
     440             :     return __sync_bool_compare_and_swap(&aPtr, ValueType(aOldVal), ValueType(aNewVal));
     441             :   }
     442             : };
     443             : 
     444             : template<typename T, MemoryOrdering Order>
     445             : struct IntrinsicAddSub
     446             :   : public IntrinsicMemoryOps<T, Order>
     447             : {
     448             :   typedef IntrinsicMemoryOps<T, Order> Base;
     449             :   typedef typename Base::ValueType ValueType;
     450             : 
     451             :   static T add(ValueType& aPtr, T aVal)
     452             :   {
     453             :     return T(__sync_fetch_and_add(&aPtr, ValueType(aVal)));
     454             :   }
     455             : 
     456             :   static T sub(ValueType& aPtr, T aVal)
     457             :   {
     458             :     return T(__sync_fetch_and_sub(&aPtr, ValueType(aVal)));
     459             :   }
     460             : };
     461             : 
     462             : template<typename T, MemoryOrdering Order>
     463             : struct IntrinsicAddSub<T*, Order>
     464             :   : public IntrinsicMemoryOps<T*, Order>
     465             : {
     466             :   typedef IntrinsicMemoryOps<T*, Order> Base;
     467             :   typedef typename Base::ValueType ValueType;
     468             : 
     469             :   /*
     470             :    * The reinterpret_casts are needed so that
     471             :    * __sync_fetch_and_{add,sub} will properly type-check.
     472             :    *
     473             :    * Also, these functions do not provide standard semantics for
     474             :    * pointer types, so we need to adjust the addend.
     475             :    */
     476             :   static ValueType add(ValueType& aPtr, ptrdiff_t aVal)
     477             :   {
     478             :     ValueType amount = reinterpret_cast<ValueType>(aVal * sizeof(T));
     479             :     return __sync_fetch_and_add(&aPtr, amount);
     480             :   }
     481             : 
     482             :   static ValueType sub(ValueType& aPtr, ptrdiff_t aVal)
     483             :   {
     484             :     ValueType amount = reinterpret_cast<ValueType>(aVal * sizeof(T));
     485             :     return __sync_fetch_and_sub(&aPtr, amount);
     486             :   }
     487             : };
     488             : 
     489             : template<typename T, MemoryOrdering Order>
     490             : struct IntrinsicIncDec : public IntrinsicAddSub<T, Order>
     491             : {
     492             :   typedef IntrinsicAddSub<T, Order> Base;
     493             :   typedef typename Base::ValueType ValueType;
     494             : 
     495             :   static T inc(ValueType& aPtr) { return Base::add(aPtr, 1); }
     496             :   static T dec(ValueType& aPtr) { return Base::sub(aPtr, 1); }
     497             : };
     498             : 
     499             : template<typename T, MemoryOrdering Order>
     500             : struct AtomicIntrinsics : public IntrinsicIncDec<T, Order>
     501             : {
     502             :   static T or_( T& aPtr, T aVal) { return __sync_fetch_and_or(&aPtr, aVal); }
     503             :   static T xor_(T& aPtr, T aVal) { return __sync_fetch_and_xor(&aPtr, aVal); }
     504             :   static T and_(T& aPtr, T aVal) { return __sync_fetch_and_and(&aPtr, aVal); }
     505             : };

     513             : struct ToStorageTypeArgument
     514             : {

     516             :

     519             : 
     520             : template<typename T>
     521             : struct ToStorageTypeArgument<T, false>
     522             : {
     523             :   static constexpr T convert (T aT) { return aT; }
     524             : };

     608       86629 :   T operator--(int) { return Base::Intrinsics::dec(Base::mValue); }
     609       77122 :   T operator++() { return Base::Intrinsics::inc(Base::mValue) + 1; }

     614             :   AtomicBaseIncDec(const AtomicBaseIncDec<T, AnyOrder>& aCopy) = delete;
     615             : };
     616             : 
     617             : } // namespace detail
     618             : 
     619             : /**
     620             :  * A wrapper for a type that enforces that all memory accesses are atomic.
     621             :  *
     622             :  * In general, where a variable |T foo| exists, |Atomic<T> foo| can be used in
     623             :  * its place.  Implementations for integral and pointer types are provided
     624             :  * below.
     625             :  *
     626             :  * Atomic accesses are sequentially consistent by default.  You should
     627             :  * use the default unless you are tall enough to ride the
     628             :  * memory-ordering roller coaster (if you're not sure, you aren't) and
     629             :  * you have a compelling reason to do otherwise.
     630             :  *
     631             :  * There is one exception to the case of atomic memory accesses: providing an
     632             :  * initial value of the atomic value is not guaranteed to be atomic.  This is a
     633             :  * deliberate design choice that enables static atomic variables to be declared
     634             :  * without introducing extra static constructors.
     635             :  */
     636             : template<typename T,
     637             :          MemoryOrdering Order = SequentiallyConsistent,
     638             :          typename Enable = void>
     639             : class Atomic;
     640             : 
     641             : /**
     642             :  * Atomic<T> implementation for integral types.
     643             :  *
     644             :  * In addition to atomic store and load operations, compound assignment and
     645             :  * increment/decrement operators are implemented which perform the
     646             :  * corresponding read-modify-write operation atomically.  Finally, an atomic
     647             :  * swap method is provided.
     648             :  */
     649             : template<typename T, MemoryOrdering Order>
     650             : class Atomic<T, Order, typename EnableIf<IsIntegral<T>::value &&
     651             :                        !IsSame<T, bool>::value>::Type>
     652             :   : public detail::AtomicBaseIncDec<T, Order>
     653             : {
     654             :   typedef typename detail::AtomicBaseIncDec<T, Order> Base;
     655             : 
     656             : public:
     657        1505 :   constexpr Atomic() : Base() {}
     658        7036 :   explicit constexpr Atomic(T aInit) : Base(aInit) {}
     659             : 
     660             :   using Base::operator=;
     661             : 
     662        1200 :   T operator+=(T aDelta)
     663             :   {
     664      105763 :     return Base::Intrinsics::add(Base::mValue, aDelta) + aDelta;
     665             :   }
     666             : 
     667         780 :   T operator-=(T aDelta)
     668             :   {
     669      431715 :     return Base::Intrinsics::sub(Base::mValue, aDelta) - aDelta;
     670             :   }
     671             : 
     672           0 :   T operator|=(T aVal)
     673             :   {
     674           0 :     return Base::Intrinsics::or_(Base::mValue, aVal) | aVal;
     675             :   }
     676             : 
     677             :   T operator^=(T aVal)
     678             :   {
     679             :     return Base::Intrinsics::xor_(Base::mValue, aVal) ^ aVal;
     680             :   }
     681             : 
     682             :   T operator&=(T aVal)
     683             :   {
     684             :     return Base::Intrinsics::and_(Base::mValue, aVal) & aVal;
     685             :   }
     686             : 
     687             : private:
     688             :   Atomic(Atomic<T, Order>& aOther) = delete;
     689             : };
     690             : 
     691             : /**
     692             :  * Atomic<T> implementation for pointer types.
     693             :  *
     694             :  * An atomic compare-and-swap primitive for pointer variables is provided, as
     695             :  * are atomic increment and decement operators.  Also provided are the compound
     696             :  * assignment operators for addition and subtraction. Atomic swap (via
     697             :  * exchange()) is included as well.
     698             :  */
     699             : template<typename T, MemoryOrdering Order>
     700             : class Atomic<T*, Order> : public detail::AtomicBaseIncDec<T*, Order>
     701             : {
     702             :   typedef typename detail::AtomicBaseIncDec<T*, Order> Base;
     703             : 
     704             : public:
     705           0 :   constexpr Atomic() : Base() {}
     706       17356 :   explicit constexpr Atomic(T* aInit) : Base(aInit) {}
     707             : 
     708             :   using Base::operator=;
     709             : 
     710             :   T* operator+=(ptrdiff_t aDelta)
     711             :   {
     712             :     return Base::Intrinsics::add(Base::mValue, aDelta) + aDelta;
     713             :   }
     714             : 
     715             :   T* operator-=(ptrdiff_t aDelta)
     716             :   {
     717             :     return Base::Intrinsics::sub(Base::mValue, aDelta) - aDelta;
     718             :   }
     719             : 
     720             : private:
     721             :   Atomic(Atomic<T*, Order>& aOther) = delete;
     722             : };
     723             : 
     724             : /**
     725             :  * Atomic<T> implementation for enum types.
     726             :  *
     727             :  * The atomic store and load operations and the atomic swap method is provided.
     728             :  */
     729             : template<typename T, MemoryOrdering Order>
     730             : class Atomic<T, Order, typename EnableIf<IsEnum<T>::value>::Type>
     731             :   : public detail::AtomicBase<T, Order>
     732             : {
     733             :   typedef typename detail::AtomicBase<T, Order> Base;
     734             : 
     735             : public:
     736        6960 :   constexpr Atomic() : Base() {}
     737        1722 :   explicit constexpr Atomic(T aInit) : Base(aInit) {}
     738             : 
     739      277400 :   operator T() const { return T(Base::Intrinsics::load(Base::mValue)); }
     740             : 
     741             :   using Base::operator=;
     742             : 
     743             : private:
     744             :   Atomic(Atomic<T, Order>& aOther) = delete;
     745             : };
     746             : 
     747             : /**
     748             :  * Atomic<T> implementation for boolean types.
     749             :  *
     750             :  * The atomic store and load operations and the atomic swap method is provided.
     751             :  *
     752             :  * Note:
     753             :  *
     754             :  * - sizeof(Atomic<bool>) != sizeof(bool) for some implementations of
     755             :  *   bool and/or some implementations of std::atomic. This is allowed in
     756             :  *   [atomic.types.generic]p9.
     757             :  *
     758             :  * - It's not obvious whether the 8-bit atomic functions on Windows are always
     759             :  *   inlined or not. If they are not inlined, the corresponding functions in the
     760             :  *   runtime library are not available on Windows XP. This is why we implement
     761             :  *   Atomic<bool> with an underlying type of uint32_t.
     762             :  */
     763             : template<MemoryOrdering Order>
     764             : class Atomic<bool, Order>
     765             :   : protected detail::AtomicBase<uint32_t, Order>
     766             : {
     767             :   typedef typename detail::AtomicBase<uint32_t, Order> Base;
     768             : 
     769             : public:
     770       22189 :   constexpr Atomic() : Base() {}
     771       69772 :   explicit constexpr Atomic(bool aInit) : Base(aInit) {}
     772             : 
     773             :   // We provide boolean wrappers for the underlying AtomicBase methods.

     776      971739 :     return Base::Intrinsics::load(Base::mValue);
     777             :   }

     782             :   }
     783             :

     785             :   {

     787             :   }
     788             :

     790             :   {
